Memorandum by the Lord Chancellor.With reference to the question marked 1 (a) in the recommendations of the above Committee (C.P. 406(26)), I think that the Bill should contain a clause to the following effect"Nothing in Section 4 of the Trade Disputes Act 1906 (which prohibits actions of tort against trade unions) shall apply to an action in respect of a tortious act alleged to have been committed by the direction or with the authority of the committee of management or other governing body of a trade union,Provided that no execution or process in the nature thereof shall be issued out of any court for enforcing payment out of the provident fund of the union of a judgment given in any such action." The prohibi tion contained in section 4 of the Trade Disputes Act 1906 has been much criticised. The Report of the Royal Commission on Trade Disputes (1906) dealt with this provision, which was then being discussed, in the following terms:-"There is no rule of law so elementary, so universal, or so indispensable as the rule that a wrong-doer should be made to redress his wrong. If trade unions were exempt from this liability Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1. 6th December, 1936*they would be the only exception, and it would then be right that that exception should be removed,. That vast and powerful institutions should be permanently licensed to apply the funds they possess to do wrong to others, and by that wrong inflict upon them damage, perhaps to the amount of many thousand pounds, and yet not be liable to make redress out of those funds, would be a state of things opposed tu the very idea of law and order and justice".. It is said that when the Bill of 1906 was under discussion some Conservatives took the view that section 4 would have little if any real effect, but after twenty . ' years1 experience of the working of the section that view can no longer be entertained.If the above clause were inserted, I think that the Bill could be shortened In other respects.., ...
